translated: 4 Abhidharma Collection of Categories, fascicle 13
Composed by Venerable Vasubandhu
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on Imperial Order

As for how many of these four noble truths are known through the knowledge of elimination, etc., two are known through the knowledge of elimination, and two are not known through the knowledge of elimination.
As for how many should be eliminated, etc., two should be eliminated, and two should not be eliminated.

As for how many should be cultivated, etc., one should be cultivated, one should not be cultivated, and two should be distinguished. This means the noble truth of suffering, which may be cultivated or not cultivated.
Why should it be cultivated?
This refers to the good truth of suffering.
Why should it not be cultivated?
This refers to the unwholesome and indeterminate truth of suffering.
The noble truth of the accumulation is also like this.
As for how many are defiled, etc., two are not defiled, and two should be distinguished. This means the noble truth of suffering, which may be defiled or not defiled.
Why is it defiled?
This refers to the truth of suffering that is covered.
Why is it not defiled?
It refers to the unobscured truth of suffering.
The noble truth of the origin is also like this.
As for how many are results but not possessors of results, three are both results and possessors of results, one is a result but not a possessor of results.
As for how many are appropriated, etc., two are not appropriated, two should be distinguished. That is, the noble truth of suffering, either appropriated or not appropriated.
How is it appropriated?
It refers to the truth of suffering included in one's own continuum.
How is it not appropriated?
It refers to the truth of suffering not included in one's own continuum.
The noble truth of the origin is also like this.
As for how many are derived from the great elements, etc., one is not derived from the great elements, three should be distinguished.
That is, the noble truth of suffering, either derived from the great elements or not derived from the great elements.
How is it derived from the great elements?
It refers to nine sense bases and a part of two sense bases.
How is it not derived from the great elements?
It refers to one sense base and a part of two sense bases.
The noble truth of the origin is also like this.
The bodily and verbal actions included in the noble truth of the path are derived from the great elements, the rest are not derived from the great elements.
As for how many have higher, etc., three have higher, one has no higher.
As for how many are existent, etc., two are existent, two are not existent.
As for how many are associated with causes, etc., one is not associated with causes, three should be distinguished.
That is to say, the form and mental factors not associated with mind included in the noble truth of suffering are not associated with causes, the rest are all associated with causes.
The noble truth of the accumulation is also like this.
The bodily and verbal actions and mental factors not associated with mind included in the noble truth of the path are not associated with causes, the rest are all associated with causes.

As for the relationship between these four noble truths and the six wholesome bases, the six wholesome bases include two truths and part of two truths, and two truths and part of two truths also include the six wholesome bases.

As for the relationship with the five unwholesome bases, the five unwholesome bases include part of two truths, and part of two truths also includes the five unwholesome bases.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
As for the correspondence with the seven indeterminate factors, four sentences should be made.
Either it is an indeterminate factor but not a truth, namely space and non-analytical cessation.ğŸ”½Either it is a truth but not an indeterminate factor, namely two truths and a part of two truths.
Either it is an indeterminate factor and also a truth, namely a part of two truths.
Either it is neither an indeterminate factor nor a truth, such a thing is impossible.
As for the correspondence with the three contaminated factors, the three contaminated factors include a part of two truths, and a part of two truths also includes the three contaminated factors.
As for the correspondence with the five contaminated factors, the five contaminated factors include two truths, and two truths also include the five contaminated factors.

As for the correspondence with the eight uncontaminated factors, four sentences should be made.ğŸ”½Either it is an uncontaminated factor but not a truth, namely space and non-analytical cessation.ğŸ”½Either it is a truth but not an uncontaminated factor, namely two truths.
Either it is an uncontaminated factor and also a truth, namely two truths.
Or it is not a non-contaminated element and not a truth, this is not possible.
As for how many are past, etc., three are either past, future, or present, one is neither past, future, nor present.
As for how many are wholesome, etc., two are wholesome, two should be distinguished.
That is to say, the noble truth of suffering is either wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate.
What is wholesome?
It refers to the wholesome five aggregates included in the truth of suffering.
What is unwholesome?
It refers to the unwholesome five aggregates included in the truth of suffering.
What is indeterminate?
It refers to the indeterminate five aggregates included in the truth of suffering.
The noble truth of the accumulation [of suffering] is also like this.
As for how many are bound to the desire realm, etc., two are unbound, two should be distinguished.
That is to say, the noble truth of suffering is either bound to the desire realm, bound to the form realm, or bound to the formless realm.
How is it bound to the desire realm?
It refers to the five aggregates of the desire realm included in the truth of suffering.
How is it bound to the form realm?
It refers to the five aggregates of the form realm included in the truth of suffering.
What is associated with the formless realm?
It refers to the four aggregates of the formless realm included in the truth of suffering.
The noble truth of the origin [of suffering] is also like this.
As for how many are learners, etc., three are neither learners nor adepts, and one should be distinguished.
That is to say, the noble truth of the path is either a learner or an adept.
What is a learner? It refers to the five aggregates of a learner.
What is an adept? It refers to the five aggregates of an adept.
As for how many of these four noble truths are eliminated by seeing, etc., two are not to be eliminated, and two should be distinguished.
That is to say, the noble truth of suffering is either eliminated by seeing or eliminated by cultivation.
What is eliminated by seeing?
It refers to the truth of suffering that is eliminated by the perseverance for the realization of the truths of the stage of the direct disciple of the faith-follower and the doctrine-follower.
What is this again?

It refers to the eighty-eight latent afflictions that are eliminated by seeing, and the truth of suffering that is associated with them, as well as the unassociated formative forces that are produced by them.
What is eliminated by cultivation?
That is, the truth of suffering that is to be eliminated by the path of cultivation of one who has entered the stage of spiritual training.
What is this again?

It refers to the ten latent afflictions that are to be eliminated by the path of cultivation, and the truth of suffering associated with them, as well as the bodily and verbal actions produced by them, and the factors not directly associated with the mind. If the truth of suffering is undefiled,
The noble truth of the origin [of suffering] is also like this.
How many are not mind, etc.? One is neither mind nor mental factor nor associated with mind, three should be distinguished.
That is, the form and factors not directly associated with the mind included in the noble truth of suffering are neither mind nor mental factors nor associated with mind;
The aggregate of feeling, the aggregate of perception, and the aggregate of formations associated with [the truth of suffering] are mental factors and are associated with mind;
The mind, thought, and consciousness are only mind.
The noble truth of the origin [of suffering] is also like this.
The bodily and verbal actions and factors not directly associated with the mind included in the noble truth of the path are neither mind nor mental factors nor associated with mind;
The aggregate of feeling, the aggregate of perception, and the aggregate of formations associated with [the truth of the path] are mental factors and are associated with mind;
The mind, thought, and consciousness are only mind.
How many are associated with thought but not with feeling? One is neither associated with thought nor with feeling, three should be distinguished.
That is, the noble truth of suffering has four alternatives.
Either associated with thought but not with feeling, referring to bodily and verbal actions, thought concomitants not directly associated with mind, and feeling.
Either associated with feeling but not with thought, referring to mind, thought, and consciousness.
Either associated with thought and also with feeling, referring to the aggregate of perception and the aggregate of thought concomitants associated with it.

Either not associated with thought nor with feeling, referring to all the other forms, and thought concomitants not directly associated with mind, excluding bodily and verbal actions associated with thought.
The noble truth of the accumulation of suffering is also like this.

The noble truth of the path has four alternatives.ğŸ”½Either associated with thought but not with feeling, referring to bodily and verbal actions, and thought concomitants not directly associated with mind, together with feeling.
Either associated with feeling but not with thought, referring to mind, thought, and consciousness.
Or, they are both concomitant with mind and associated with feeling, namely, the aggregate of perception and the aggregate of formations associated with mind.
Or, they are neither concomitant with mind nor associated with feeling, namely, those formations dissociated from mind that are not concomitant with mind.
How many are concomitant with mind but not associated with perception and thought? Except for their own nature, they should be understood like feeling.
How many are concomitant with investigation but not with deliberation? One is not concomitant with investigation but associated with deliberation, and three should be distinguished.
That is to say, the noble truth of suffering has four alternatives.

Either concomitant with investigation but not associated with deliberation, namely, bodily and verbal actions and formations dissociated from mind that are concomitant with investigation, and deliberation associated with investigation.

Or associated with deliberation but not concomitant with investigation, namely, investigation and the mind and mental factors associated with deliberation but not associated with investigation, and the truth of suffering.
Or concomitant with investigation and also associated with deliberation, namely, the mind and mental factors associated with both investigation and deliberation, and the truth of suffering.

Or it is neither concomitant with applied thought nor associated with sustained thought, namely, excluding the bodily and verbal actions that are concomitant with applied thought and the dissociated factors, as well as the other form and the dissociated factors, and sustained thought that is not associated with applied thought, and the truth of suffering that is neither with applied thought nor sustained thought.
The noble truth of the accumulation of suffering is also like this.
The noble truth of the path has four alternatives.

Or it is concomitant with applied thought but not associated with sustained thought, namely, the bodily and verbal actions that are concomitant with applied thought and the dissociated factors, and the sustained thought associated with applied thought.

Or it is associated with sustained thought but not concomitant with applied thought, namely, the applied thought and the mental factors and states of mind that are associated with sustained thought but not associated with applied thought.

Or it is concomitant with applied thought and also associated with sustained thought, namely, the mental factors and states of mind that are associated with both applied thought and sustained thought.

Or it is neither concomitant with applied thought nor associated with sustained thought, namely, excluding the bodily and verbal actions and the dissociated factors that are concomitant with applied thought, the other bodily and verbal actions and the dissociated factors, and the sustained thought that is not associated with applied thought, and the mental factors and states of mind that are neither with applied thought nor sustained thought.
How many are seeing and not objects of seeing, etc.? One is neither seeing nor an object of seeing, three should be distinguished.
That is to say, the noble truth of suffering, either seeing and also an object of seeing, or an object of seeing but not seeing.
Either seeing and also an object of seeing refers to the eye faculty, the five defiled views, and worldly right views. The rest are all objects of seeing but not seeing.
The noble truth of accumulation is also like this.

The wisdom not included in the knowledge of elimination and non-arising included in the noble truth of the path is seeing and not an object of seeing. The rest are all neither seeing nor objects of seeing.

How many have the view of self as real for their cause but are not causes of the view of self as real, etc.? Two do not have the view of self as real for their cause but are not causes of the view of self as real. Two should be distinguished.

translated: That is to say, the noble truth of suffering, either having the view of self as real for its cause but not a cause of the view of self as real, or having the view of self as real for its cause and also being a cause of the view of self as real, or not having the view of self as real for its cause and not being a cause of the view of self as real.

The truth of suffering that is a cause of the view of self but is not a cause of the view of self is: except for the past and present contaminants abandoned by seeing suffering and the truth of suffering associated with them and coexisting with them, also except for the past and present pervasive contaminants abandoned by seeing the cause and the truth of suffering associated with them and coexisting with them, also except for the future truth of suffering associated with the cause of the view of self, also except for the future view of self and the birth, aging, duration, and impermanence associated with it, all other defiled truths of suffering.
The truth of suffering that is a cause of the view of self and is also a cause of the view of self is: the truth of suffering that was previously excluded.
The truth of suffering that is neither a cause of the view of self nor a cause of the view of self is: the undefiled truth of suffering.
The same applies to the noble truth of the origin.

As for how many are karma and how many are not karma, how many are karmic retribution and how many are not karmic retribution, one is neither karma nor karmic retribution, and three should be distinguished.
That is to say, the noble truth of suffering has four statements.
Either it is karma but not karmic retribution, referring to bodily and verbal karma, and volition not included in karmic retribution.
Or, it is karmic retribution but not karma, namely, the truth of suffering that is born of karmic retribution and is not volition.
Or, it is both karma and karmic retribution, namely, volition that is born of karmic retribution.
Or, it is neither karma nor karmic retribution, namely, all the truths of suffering except for those born of karma and karmic retribution.
The same applies to the noble truth of the origin.
Bodily and verbal actions and volition included in the noble truth of the path are karma but not karmic retribution; the rest are neither.
How many are karma but not concomitant with karma, etc.? One is neither karma nor concomitant with karma; three should be distinguished.
That is, the noble truth of suffering has four alternatives.
Either it is karma but not concomitant with karma, namely, all bodily and verbal actions except those concomitant with karma, and volition.

Or, it is concomitant with karma but not karma, namely, the aggregates of feeling, perception, and consciousness, and the aggregate of formations not included in volition that is concomitant with karma.
Or, it is both karma and concomitant with karma, namely, bodily and verbal actions that are concomitant with karma.
Or neither action nor concomitant with action, namely, excluding action and that which is concomitant with action, the rest of the truth of suffering.
The noble truth of the accumulation is also like this.
The noble truth of the path has four sentences.
Or action but not concomitant with action, namely, volition.
Or concomitant with action but not action, namely, the aggregates of feeling, perception, and consciousness, and the compositional factors not subsumed in volition that are concomitant with action.
Or both action and concomitant with action, namely, bodily and verbal action.

Or neither action nor concomitant with action, namely, excluding the compositional factors not directly associated with mind that are concomitant with action, the rest of the compositional factors not directly associated with mind.
How many are derivative form but not visible form, etc.? One is neither derivative form nor visible form. Three should be distinguished.
Namely, the noble truth of suffering has three sentences.
Or derivative form but not visible form, namely, eight sense bases and part of two sense bases.
Or derivative form and also visible form, namely, one sense base.
Or, it is not derivative form and not visible form, namely one sense base and part of two sense bases.
The same applies to the truth of accumulation.
Bodily and verbal actions included in the truth of the path are derivative form but not visible form, the rest are neither derivative form nor visible form.
As for how many of these four noble truths are derivative form but not resistant form, etc., one is neither derivative form nor resistant form, three should be distinguished.
That is to say, the truth of suffering has four alternatives.ğŸ”½Either it is derivative form but not resistant form, namely part of one sense base.
Or it is resistant form but not derivative form, namely part of one sense base.
Or it is derivative form and also resistant form, namely nine sense bases and part of one sense base.
Or it is neither derivative form nor resistant form, namely one sense base and part of one sense base.
The same applies to the truth of accumulation.
The bodily and verbal actions included in the noble truth of the path are derivative form but not resistant form, the rest are neither derivative form nor resistant form.
As for how many are difficult to see and therefore profound, etc., all are difficult to see and therefore profound, and profound and therefore difficult to see.

As for how many are wholesome but not causes of the wholesome, etc., one is wholesome but not a cause of the wholesome, one is both wholesome and a cause of the wholesome, and two should be distinguished.
That is, the noble truth of suffering has three sentences.
Either it is a cause of the wholesome but not wholesome, namely the truth of suffering born of wholesome karmic maturation.
Either it is both wholesome and a cause of the wholesome, namely the wholesome truth of suffering.
Either it is neither wholesome nor a cause of the wholesome, namely the truth of suffering that is neutral and unwholesome, excluding the truth of suffering born of wholesome karmic maturation.
The noble truth of the accumulation is also like this.
As for how many are unwholesome but not causes of the unwholesome, etc., two are neither unwholesome nor causes of the unwholesome, and two should be distinguished.
That is, the noble truth of suffering has three sentences.

Or, it is not unwholesome as cause but is unwholesome, namely, the truth of suffering that is the karmic ripening of unwholesome [karma], and the afflicted view of self and extreme view belonging to the desire realm, as well as the truth of suffering associated with and coexisting with them.
Or, it is both unwholesome and unwholesome as cause, namely, the truth of suffering that is unwholesome.

Or, it is neither unwholesome nor unwholesome as cause, namely, the truth of suffering that is karmically ripening but not unwholesome, and the truth of suffering that is associated with and coexisting with the afflicted view of self and extreme view belonging to the desire realm, and all other wholesome and indeterminate truths of suffering.
The same applies to the noble truth of the origin.
As for how many are indeterminate but not indeterminate as cause, etc., two are neither indeterminate nor indeterminate as cause, and two should be distinguished.

That is to say, the noble truth of suffering has three phrases.ğŸ”½Or, it is a cause of the indeterminate but is not indeterminate, namely, the truth of suffering that is unwholesome.ğŸ”½Or, it is indeterminate and also a cause of the indeterminate, namely, the truth of suffering that is indeterminate.
Or, it is neither indeterminate nor a cause of the indeterminate, namely, the truth of suffering that is wholesome.
The same applies to the truth of accumulation.

translated: How many are conditions and also have causes, etc.? Three are conditions and also have causes, one is not a condition and does not have causes.
How many are immediately preceding but not immediately preceding conditions, etc.? One is not immediately preceding and not an immediately preceding condition, three should be distinguished.

That is to say, the noble truth of suffering has three phrases.ğŸ”½Either it is immediately preceding but not an immediately preceding condition, referring to the mind and mental factors of the truth of suffering that are presently arising in the future, and the mind and mental factors of the truth of suffering at the end of the life of an arhat in the past and present, as well as the already arisen and presently occurring states of non-perception and cessation.

Either it is immediately preceding and also an immediately preceding condition, referring to all the past and present mind and mental factors of the truth of suffering, excluding the mind and mental factors of the truth of suffering at the end of the life of an arhat in the past and present.

Or neither similar and immediately antecedent nor similar and immediately antecedent conditions, namely, excluding the future present arising mind and mental factors of the truth of suffering, all other future mind and mental factors of the truth of suffering, excluding the similar and immediately antecedent non-associated compositional factors, all other non-associated compositional factors, and the form truth of suffering.
The noble truth of the accumulation is also so.
The noble truth of the path has three cases.
Either similar and immediately antecedent but not similar and immediately antecedent conditions, namely, the future present arising mind and mental factors of the truth of the path.
Either similar and immediately antecedent and similar and immediately antecedent conditions, namely, the past and present mind and mental factors of the truth of the path.

Or neither similar and immediately antecedent nor similar and immediately antecedent conditions, namely, excluding the future present arising mind and mental factors of the truth of the path, all other future mind and mental factors of the truth of the path, and the bodily and verbal actions, and the mind and mental factors not associated with the truth of the path.

As for how many are objects of observation conditions but do not have objects of observation, one is an object of observation condition but does not have an object of observation, and three should be analyzed.

That is, form and the forces not associated with mind included in the truth of suffering are causal conditions but do not have objects, while the rest of the truth of suffering are both causal conditions and have objects.
The same is so of the truth of the origin of suffering.

Bodily and verbal actions and the forces not associated with mind included in the truth of the path are causal conditions but do not have objects, while the rest of the truth of the path are both causal conditions and have objects.
How many are dominant conditions but are not dominant? One is a dominant condition but is not dominant, and three are dominant conditions and are also dominant.
How many are floods but not in accord with floods? One is neither a flood nor in accord with floods, and two must be discriminated.
That is, the truth of suffering is either a flood and also in accord with floods, or in accord with floods but not a flood.
That which is a flood and also in accord with floods is the four floods.
The rest of the truth of suffering is in accord with floods but not a flood.
The same is so of the truth of the origin of suffering.
The four meditations are the first meditation, the second meditation, the third meditation, and the fourth meditation.
As for how many have form, etc., all should be distinguished. That is, the bodily and verbal actions included in the meditations have form, the rest are all formless.
As for how many are visible, etc., all are invisible.
As for how many are resistant, etc., all are non-resistant.
As for how many are contaminated, etc., all should be distinguished. That is, the meditations may be either contaminated or uncontaminated.
What are the contaminated ones?
The contaminated five aggregates included in the meditations.
What are the uncontaminated ones?
The uncontaminated five aggregates included in the meditations.
As for how many are conditioned, etc., all are conditioned.
As for how many have karmic retribution, etc., all should be distinguished. That is, the meditations, if contaminated, have karmic retribution; if uncontaminated, they have no karmic retribution.
As for how many are conditionally originated, etc.: all are conditionally originated, originated from causes, and included in the mundane.

As for how many are categorized as form, etc.: all should be discriminated. That is to say, the bodily and verbal karma included in the various meditations is categorized as form, and the rest are all categorized as name.

As for how many are categorized as internal sense bases, etc.: all should be discriminated. That is to say, the mind, thought, and consciousness included in the various meditations are categorized as internal sense bases, and the rest are all categorized as external sense bases.
As for how many are known by the knowledge of the knowable, etc.: all are known by the knowledge of the knowable.

As for how many are known by the thorough knowledge of elimination, etc.: all should be discriminated. That is to say, the various meditations, if contaminated, are known by the thorough knowledge of elimination, but if uncontaminated, they are not known by the thorough knowledge of elimination.

As for how many are to be eliminated, etc.: all should be discriminated. That is to say, the various meditations, if contaminated, are to be eliminated, but if uncontaminated, they are not to be eliminated.
As for how many are to be cultivated, etc.: all are to be cultivated.
As for how many are defiled and so on, all are undefiled.
As for how many are results but not karmic maturations and so on, all are results and also have karmic maturations.
As for how many are conjoined and so on, all are not conjoined.

As for how many are derived from the four great elements and so on, all should be discriminated. That is to say, the bodily and verbal actions included in the various meditations are derived from the four great elements, the rest are not derived from the four great elements.
As for how many have higher levels and so on, all have higher levels.
As for how many are existents and so on, all should be discriminated. That is to say, the various meditations, if contaminated, are existents, if uncontaminated, are not existents.

As for how many are associated with causes and so on, all should be discriminated. That is to say, the bodily and verbal actions and factors not directly associated with the mind included in the various meditations are not associated with causes, the rest are all associated with causes.

As for the inclusion of the four meditations and the six wholesome bases, a part of the five wholesome bases includes the four meditations, and the four meditations also include a part of the five wholesome bases.
As for the relationship between the four formless concentrations and the five unwholesome bases, they do not mutually include each other.
As for the relationship between the four formless concentrations and the seven indeterminate bases, they do not mutually include each other.
As for the relationship between the four formless concentrations and the three bases of defilement, they do not mutually include each other.
As for the relationship between the four formless concentrations and the five bases of defilement, four sentences should be made.
There may be a base of defilement that is not a formless concentration, namely the five aggregates of defilement that are not included in the formless concentrations.
There may be a formless concentration that is not a base of defilement, namely the four formless concentrations that are pure.
There may be a base of defilement that is also a formless concentration, namely the four formless concentrations that are impure.

There may be something that is neither a base of defilement nor a formless concentration, namely the five aggregates of purity that are not included in the formless concentrations, and unconditioned dharmas.
As for the relationship between the four formless concentrations and the eight bases of purity, four sentences should be made.
There may be a base of purity that is not a formless concentration, namely the five aggregates of purity that are not included in the formless concentrations, and unconditioned dharmas.
There may be a formless concentration that is not a base of purity, namely the four formless concentrations that are impure.
Or they are both the formless concentrations and also the formless realms, namely the four formless concentrations.
Or they are neither the formless concentrations nor the formless realms, namely the contaminated five aggregates not included in the formless concentrations.
As for how many are past, etc., all are either past, future, or present.
As for how many are wholesome, etc., all are wholesome.
As for how many are bound to the desire realm, etc., all should be analyzed. The concentrations, if contaminated, are bound to the form realm; if uncontaminated, they are unbound.
As for how many are the learner's path, etc., all should be analyzed. The concentrations are either the learner's path, the adept's path, or neither the learner's path nor the adept's path.
What is the learner's path?
It refers to the five aggregates of the learner included in the concentrations.
What is the adept's path?
It refers to the five aggregates of the adept included in the concentrations.
What is neither the learner's path nor the adept's path?
It refers to the five contaminated aggregates included in the concentrations.

As for how many of these four meditations are to be eliminated by seeing, etc., all should be distinguished. It is said that the various meditations, if contaminated, are to be eliminated by cultivation, but if uncontaminated, they are not to be eliminated.

As for how many are not mind, etc., all should be distinguished. It is said that the bodily and verbal actions and formations not directly associated with the mind included in the meditations are not mind, nor are they mental factors, nor are they directly associated with mind;
the aggregate of feeling, the aggregate of perception, and the aggregate of formations associated with the mind are mental factors and are directly associated with the mind;
the mind, thought, and consciousness are only mind.

As for how many are concomitant with the mind but not associated with feeling, etc., all should be distinguished. It is said that each has four alternatives.ğŸ”½Either concomitant with the mind but not associated with feeling, referring to bodily and verbal actions and formations that are concomitant with the mind but not directly associated with the mind included in the meditations, as well as feeling.ğŸ”½Either associated with feeling but not concomitant with the mind, referring to the mind, thought, and consciousness included in the meditations.
Either concomitant with the mind and also associated with feeling, referring to the aggregate of perception included in the meditations and the aggregate of formations associated with the mind.

Or they are neither concomitant with mind nor associated with feeling. This refers to the formations dissociated from mind included in the formless absorptions, excluding those that are concomitant with mind.
How many are concomitant with mind but not associated with thought? Excluding their own nature, they should be understood like feeling.
How many are concomitant with investigation but not with deliberation? Three are neither concomitant with investigation nor associated with deliberation. One should be distinguished.
That is to say, the first absorption should be classified into four categories.

Or they are concomitant with investigation but not associated with deliberation. This refers to bodily and verbal actions included in the first absorption, and the formations dissociated from mind that are concomitant with investigation, as well as deliberation.
Or they are associated with deliberation but not concomitant with investigation. This refers to investigation included in the first absorption.

Or they are concomitant with investigation and also associated with deliberation. This refers to the mind and mental factors included in the first absorption that are associated with investigation and deliberation.
